comments.content_original_markup:
I'll write one for Treecko.


Sceptile @ Sceptilite
Ability: Overgrow > Lightningrod
- Giga Drain/ Leaf Storm
- Earthquake
- Dragon Claw
- Rock Slide

Mudkip will be better for your Water HM user, and Blaziken has better type advantage, but guess what? I have a soft spot for Treecko.

Wait until L21 to evolve Treecko, because it can only get Giga Drain at that point. You can replace Giga Drain later for Leaf Storm or Leaf Blade if you want Sceptile to be fully physical, but Giga Drain is really useful early on. If you ever need Giga Drain again, you can reteach it; you don't have that option if you let Treecko evolve at L16.

Other moves are pretty standard. Sceptile has a nice physical movepool, so it's highly viable to have Leaf Storm as your sole special move and 3 other physical moves to allow Sceptile to stay in after using Leaf Storm. Other good moves you can consider are Brick Break, X-Scissor, Power-Up Punch and False Swipe (to catch Pokemon).


Linoone
Ability: Pick Up
- Cut
- Strength
- Rock Smash
- Headbutt

Hoenn = Linoone
Linoone = Pick Up
Pick Up = free crap

Lets be honest, what Hoenn team is complete without Linoone. Aside from giving you free stuff, Linoone also doubles as a pretty good HM user, and a decent battle Pokemon with only Headbutt. Of course Ghost is a problem, but if your entire team is wiped and Linoone is your only surviving Pokemon, you're in serious trouble anyway. If you really want to, you can replace Headbutt with Surf for another HM move, or Shadow Claw for better coverage. You can delete all HM moves once at the E4 and Linoone is good to deal with Phoebe.


Tentacruel @ Black Sludge
Ability: Clear Body/ Liquid Ooze
- Surf
- Sludge Wave
- Waterfall/ Dazzling Gleam
- Dive/ Ice Beam

You can get Tentacruel pretty easily and early on, and it'll serve as good HM slave for all the water you need to deal with in Hoenn. While it has mediocre attacking stats (70/80 respectively), it does have access to 3 HM moves and nice typing to cover both Sceptile and Linoone's weaknesses. After you get to the E4, you can delete your HM moves and give Tentacruel more useful moves in Dazzling Gleam/ Ice Beam.

If you want, you can replace Tentacruel with Sharpedo, but it does have shoddy defences and it's rather lack luster without Speed Boost. Milotic is also another option, but evolving Feebas is a hassle.


Magnezone @ Magnet
Ability: Sturdy
- Thunderbolt
- Flash Canon
- Tri Attack
- (filler move)

Not the most brilliant move pool in the world, but the Electric/ Steel typing really helps. Magnezone will be great help against Norman and Winona, but watch out for Earthquake on Altaria. I'm pretty sure Slaking doesn't pack Earthquake, but just bear that in mind as well. If you're worried about Earthquake, you can use Magnet Rise as your final move, or either Reflect or Light Screen if you're not too fussed about it.


Swellow @ Sharp Beak
Ability: Guts
- Fly
- Roost
- Return/ Facade
- Steel Wing

Swellow is probably the best Fly user in Hoenn, except for Crobat; the others are a bit lacking in attack to make use of Fly in battle. Return is probably the better option, since it'll do 102 STAB consistently not the regular 70 STAB from Facade. Steel Wing is the most viable move for the last slot, since Swellow has a pretty shallow movepool. U-Turn is an option, but in-game you can switch when you need to.

As said, Crobat is another option, but on this team it shares Phsyic weakness with Tentacruel, who you can always replace with Sharpedo.


Froslass @ Expert Belt/ Wise Glasses
Ability: Snow Cloak
- Ice Beam/ Frost Breath
- Shadow Ball
- Thunderbolt
- Confuse Ray

Froslass is pretty good BoltBeam user, with passable sp. atk and good speed. A bit of a hassle to get, but I do really like Froslass, so I've included her. Frost Breath is better in most cases, because it'll be 120 STAB rather than 90, bar random Shell Armour Pokemon. Shadow Ball for other STAB, and Confuse Ray just to be annoying.

If you're playing during the special shiny Beldum event, I would say replace Froslass with Metagross.


Metagross @ Expert Belt
Ability: Clear Body
- Meteor Mash/ Power-Up Punch
- Zen Headbutt/ Psychic
- Bullet Punch
- Earthquake

So while Meteor Mash is really great STAB, it lacks reliability and accuracy. Power-Up punch is better just because it will always raise attack and is 100% accurate. The other moves are pretty self explanatory, although you can use a mixed set with Psychic > Zen Headbutt for accuracy.

comments.content_original_markup:
Well here's mine:

Blaziken

Ability: Blaze
Moves:
- Flare Blitz
- Brave Bird
- High Jump Kick
- Earthquake (TM) / Stone Edge (TM)

You can teach Blaziken Flare Blitz and High Jump Kick by going to the Move Reminder and exchanging one Heart Scale per move. Otherwise use Blaze Kick and Sky Uppercut, which you learn by levelling up.

TM26 Earthquake can be found in the Sea Floor Cavern.
TM71 Stone Edge can be purchased from the Lilycove Department Store for 30,000 Pokémon Dollars.

Metagross

Ability: Clear Body (this is a very good Ability, especially considering the amount of Pokémon that use stat lowering moves such as Growl and Screech in game.)
Moves:
- Meteor Mash
- Zen Headbutt
- Earthquake (TM)*
- Bullet Punch / Agility

Obviously this is obtained via the Shiny Beldum Event. It is equipped with the Metagrossite, so feel free to Mega Evolve it in battle.

*TM26 Earthquake can be found in the Sea Floor Cavern.

Linoone

Ability: Pickup (picks up items along the way, which can help you in game).
Moves:
- Cut (HM)
- Strength (HM)
- Rock Smash (HM)
- Surf (HM) / Dig (TM)*

Linoone is basically a HM Slave with Cut, Strength and Rock Smash. Dig can be used in the same way as an Escape Rope to escape caves and Surf can be used to surf at a normal speed (since we also have Sharpedo in the party). When navigating around tight bends, where if you go too fast you'll end up on the shore, that is when having a normal speed surfer pays off. Surf should be used until you catch a Carvanha on Route 118 and teach it Surf, then you can delete Surf if you so wish by going to the Move Deleter in Lilycove City.

I won't list the locations of the HM's since they're needed to complete the game anyway.

*TM28 Dig can be obtained on Route 114.

Gardevoir

Ability: Synchronize (Synchronize passes poison, paralyze, or burn to the Pokémon that inflicted it.)

Moves:
- Psychic
- Calm Mind
- Magical Leaf
- Moon Blast/Dazzling Gleam

Ralts can be obtained in a horde encounter on Route 104.

Magical Leaf comes in handy against Water/Ground types that Manectric can't touch, as well as Rock/Ground types. Moonblast can be learnt at level 62, however it can be learnt sooner by going to the Move Reminder and getting him to teach it, it in exchange for a Heat Scale. Dazzling Gleam is an alternative option, not as powerful but strikes multiple enemies which is useful for hordes.

Swellow

Ability: Guts
Moves:
- Fly
- Façade (TM)
- Steel Wing (TM)
- Roost (sneaking up/TM)*

TM19 Roost is awarded to the player as a Prize for defeating Winona, the Fortree Gym Leader.
TM42 Façade can be purchased in Mauville City for 10,000 Pokémon Dollars.
*TM51 Steel Wing can be found in Granite Cave.

Manectric

Ability: Static/Lightning Rod
Moves:
- Discharge
- Overheat (TM)
- Volt Switch (TM)
- Hidden Power (TM) / Flash (TM) / Thunder Wave (TM)*

If Manectric has a good Hidden Power type such as Ice, Grass or Water keep Hidden Power as your main move, otherwise discard it. Flash improves your visibility in dark caves, although it isn't really needed. What I did, since you can get Hidden Power and Flash as TM's quite early in the game is, I taught Manectric Flash when I needed it, after it was of no use to me, I retaught it Hidden Power again. Thunder Wave can be used in the same way, since it learns Thunder Wave through levelling up and you get Thunder Wave as a TM quite early in game. You can teach Manectric Thunder Wave if you don't get the Hidden Power type you want, or for when you are about to catch a Legendary Pokémon.

TM10 Hidden Power can be obtained in Fortree City.
TM50 Overheat is awarded to the player as a prize for defeating Flannery.
TM70 Flash can be obtained in Granite Cave.
TM72 Volt Switch is awarded to the player as a prize for defeating Wattson.
*TM73 Thunder Wave can be pruchased in Slateport City for 5000 Pokémon Dollars.

Sharpedo

Ability: Rough Skin
Moves:
- Crunch
- Surf (HM)
- Dive (HM)
- Waterfall (HM)

I won't bother listing the locations of these HM's, since their necessary to complete the game anyway.

You can get a Carvanha with a Good Rod on Route 118, however they aren't very common so you'll have to keep trying until you get one. Route 118 is also the location you get the Good Rod.

Waterfall is Sharpedo main attacking Water move and allows you to climb waterfalls, Surf is excellent on Sharpedo, as it moves twice as fast when surfing and Dive allows you to dive underwater and explore beneath the sea.

Now you may have noticed that there is actually seven Pokémon here not six, that is because I rotate my Pokémon around every so often. Linoone is always in the party, as he is my HM Slave, however he is never used in battle. Swellow and Sharpedo are also constantly in the party, while Blaziken, Metagross, Gardevoir and Manectric are constantly rotated, that way by the time I get to the Pokémon League I'll have a full party of six that are battle ready, having replaced Linoone.

comments.content_original_markup:
Sceptile

Swords Dance- Most of the useful moves Sceptile can learn are physical. Swords dance boosts its already decent attack and makes it a good physical sweeper, especially when mega evolved.
Leaf Blade- Good power, STAB
Dragon Claw- Good power, STAB when Sceptile is mega evolved
Rock Slide- Coverage against many of Sceptile's weaknesses


Swellow

Fly- Good power, STAB, useful in-game
Steel Wing- Covers steel and ice weaknesses
Endeavor- Swellow has bad defenses and will have low health often. This move will be handy then.
U-Turn- Good power, allows you to switch Pokemon without wasting a turn.


Gallade

Close Combat/Brick Break- Your call. Close combat does more power but has lower pp and lowers your defenses. Both have STAB and good power.
Psycho Cut- Decent power, STAB
Hypnosis- Puts enemy to sleep.
Night Slash- Decent power, covers ghost weakness.


Tentacruel

Surf- Good power, STAB, useful in-game
Ice Beam- Good power, covers grass weakness
Sludge Bomb- Good power, STAB
Toxic Spikes/Toxic- Again, your call. Toxic only affects one Pokemon, but badly poisons it. Toxic spikes has to be used twice to badly poison, but it affects the whole team.


Magnezone

Thunderbolt- Good power, STAB
Flash Cannon- Good power, STAB
Thunder Wave- Paralyzes target
Metal Sound- Harshly lowers opponent's special defense and pretty much makes Magnezone unstoppable.


Camerupt

Overheat- Great power, STAB
Flamethrower- Has lower power than overheat, but covers for Overheat's low pp.
Earth Power- Good power, STAB
Stone Edge- Great power. There are others moves you could use here, like Sunny Day or Amnesia. Your call.

Ice Beam- Good power, covers grass weakness  
Sludge Bomb- Good power, STAB  
Toxic Spikes/Toxic- Again, your call. Toxic only affects one Pokemon, but
badly poisons it. Toxic spikes has to be used twice to badly poison, but it
affects the whole team.

![enter image description here](What%20is%20a%20good%20in-
game%20team%20for%20Omega%20Ruby%20and%20Alpha%20Sapphire%20%20-%20Pok%C3%A9Base%20Pok%C3%A9mon%20Answers_files/image_008.png)  
Magnezone

Thunderbolt- Good power, STAB  
Flash Cannon- Good power, STAB  
Thunder Wave- Paralyzes target  
Metal Sound- Harshly lowers opponent's special defense and pretty much makes
Magnezone unstoppable.

![enter image description here](What%20is%20a%20good%20in-
game%20team%20for%20Omega%20Ruby%20and%20Alpha%20Sapphire%20%20-%20Pok%C3%A9Base%20Pok%C3%A9mon%20Answers_files/camerupt.jpg)  
Camerupt

Overheat- Great power, STAB  
Flamethrower- Has lower power than overheat, but covers for Overheat's low pp.  
Earth Power- Good power, STAB  
Stone Edge- Great power. There are others moves you could use here, like Sunny
Day or Amnesia. Your call.

comments.content_original_markup:
Im gonna make a team for Swampert here as I beat the whole story mode (Including delta series) in two days and never died once. (I know right lol)

Swampert @ Swamperite
Ability: Torrent
-Hammer Arm Great move
-Ice Beam Coverage
-Earthquake STAB
-Waterfall STAB

Swampert is my personal favorite of the three starters. Who needs an Uber starter and the only grass dragon type ;-;. But anyways swampert is a great pick because he fills the spot for water hm user and he has a great movepool. He has high defenses and attack so make sure you have physical hits if you swap any moves out.

Metagross/Aggron@ Leftovers
Ability: Clearbody/Iron Head
Metagross
-Meteor Mash STAB move and raises attack
-Psychic (Switchable with Zen Headbutt)
-Ice Punch Coverage
-Earthquake coverage
Aggron
-Earthquake Coverage
-Iron Head Very good with iron head ability
-Stone Edge Nice overall attack
-Double Edge High damage attack that almost all Aggrons have

Every team needs that tank that makes everyone mad when it endures everything you throw at it. Aggron may have higher defenses but Metagross has psychic to help with fighting types and has great attack. Either of these Pokemon would work as they are both very good tanks.

Gardevoir@ Life orb or Gardevoirite (If your having trouble finding those items go for leftovers)
Ability: Trace (Very hard to find its hidden ability)
-Moonblast Do I need to say way?
-Psychic great move for the high special attack
-Shadow Ball Helps you against other psychic types
-Thunderbolt Coverage

Gardevoir is a great special attacker with an amazing movepool. Every team needs a head psychic type and Gardevoir is a great pick. You could also go with alakazam but I just love gardevoir.

Raichu/ Jolteon@Airballoon
Ability: Static/ Volt Absorb
Jolteon
-Thunderbolt High accuracy and great damage
-Shadow Ball Very good move and suprisingly compatible with Jolteon
-Signal Beam Gosh darn grass Pokemon will eat you alive without it
-Discharge Another high accuracy and great damage attack
Raichu: Volt Tackle or Discharge, Iron Tail, Brick Break
-Volt Tackle/Discharge STAB
-Iron Tail
-Brick Break
-Fake out/ Focus Blast

Your going to need an electric type. It has great coverage and usually very fast. Jolteon and Raichu both are amazing but it can be a little hard to find a thunder stone so another option is manetric

Heracross@ Expert Belt
Ability: Guts
-MegaHorn STAB
-Close Combat STAB
-Stone Edge Coverage
-Swords Dance Self explanitory

Heragross is a very good physical sweeper with an interesting typing neutraling out some disadvantages

Latios/Latias@Latiosite/Latiasite or Souldew
Ability: Levitate
-Psychic Good move for special attack
-Recover regeneration helps
-Shadow Ball great move
-Surf/Dive as it is needed for the story mode (I hate dive so much and I'm glad some games don't require you to have it D:)

Every team needs a dragon type and latios/latias are great. Steven gives you one early on (Based on game) and is a great partner. They have a really good movepool and who wouldn't want to fly around the huge hoenn region on a dragon?!

comments.content_original_markup:
I'm making my Swampert team that I used to beat the game.

Swampert @ Swapertite
Ability: Torrent > Swift Swim
- Waterfall
- Earthquake
- Power-Up Punch
- Rockslide/ Stone Edge/ Facade/ Dive

Nothing is greater than a Swampert. Nothing. Except for it's mega evolution which really just makes it kinda OP.
Because his Attack was already pretty good compared to his Spec. Attack and with his 'roids there was no doubt about whether or not it would be a physical set. Waterfall is a good STAB move and with his huge Attack it just gets better. Earthquake is Earthquake , no explanation needed. Power-Up Punch is just there to make his Attack even more OP, and the rest are coverage or fillers.

Exploud @ Leftovers
Ability: Soundproof
- Boomburst
- Surf
- Flamethrower
- Extrasensory/ Shadow Ball

Exploud is a decent Pokémon with stats that always tend to lean towards the Spec. Attack. So Ah- Ha we have our first Special-Attacker! Boomburst is a fantastic move with a base power of 140 and 210 with STAB. Surf is a good move and is your means of water transportation. Flamethrower is a good move that provides coverage and takes out the pesky grass types. The last slot is a coverage holder. You can have Extrasensory to annihilate your fighting type weakness (which you get through sneaking), or Shadow Ball which you can use to take out Phoebe the second of the Elite 4.

Magnezone @ Magnet
Ability: Sturdy
- Thunderbolt/ Thunder
- Flash Cannon
- Tri Attack
- Mirror Coat/ Rain Dance

Magnezone is a beast. His defenses aren't that bad so he can hold in there longer than most and he has a really good Spec. Attack. Tri Attack is a decent move and is really just a filler and Flash Cannon is your Steel type STAB. Thunderbolt is a great move and fits better with the Mirror Coat set. Thunder becomes totally OP when you add Rain Dance to it and if you send out a Mega Swampert (Swolepert) his speed will double making him just that much more over-powered.
P.S. If you choose not to evolve your Magneton and just give him the Eviolite from route 123 he has less HP and less in both Attacks than Magnezone, but every other stat gets better.

Altaria @ Altarianite
Ability: Natural Cure > Pixilate
- Dragon Pulse
- Moon Blast
- Echoed Voice
- Fire Blast/ Flamethrower

Altaria is my favorite Drgon type you can obtain in the Hoenn (Besides Flygon). This Pokémon is a beast in Battle and in the Contests. Dragon Pulse is your main Dragon type move and is coverage against other Dragons. Moon Blast is a great move as is, and just gets better when you mega evolve. Echoed Voice was my Swablu's best buddy till it evolved and I just couldn't part with it, not to mention how much better it gets wit Pixilate. Fire Blast ,and Flamethrower are great moves, but I prefer Fire Blast because of Contests.

I know, I know, no Pokémon has Fly , Dive , Strength or Rock Smash and that's because I just waited to get the Eon Flute before doing any Flying and the rest was just me switching out random HM Slaves and other Pokémon to do what was necessary.

I hope this helped, 

 ToatsMuhGoats

I have been experimenting with other Pokémon in my Alpha Sapphire , and Gallade has been phenomenal. I kinda cheated a little and brought a Dawn Stone over from my Pokémon Y version so I could have a Power-house early on and he just rocks it. Here's his set-up:

Gallade @ Galladite
Ability: Steadfast > Inner Focus
- Psycho Cut
- Power-Up Punch

comments.content_text:
I'm making my Swampert team that I used to beat the game.

Swampert @ Swapertite  
Ability: Torrent > Swift Swim  
\- Waterfall  
\- Earthquake  
\- Power-Up Punch  
\- Rockslide/ Stone Edge/ Facade/ Dive

Nothing is greater than a Swampert. Nothing. Except for it's mega evolution
which really just makes it kinda OP.  
Because his Attack was already pretty good compared to his Spec. Attack and
with his 'roids there was no doubt about whether or not it would be a physical
set. **Waterfall** is a good STAB move and with his huge Attack it just gets
better. **Earthquake** is **Earthquake** , no explanation needed. **Power-Up
Punch** is just there to make his Attack even more OP, and the rest are
coverage or fillers.

Exploud @ Leftovers  
Ability: Soundproof  
\- Boomburst  
\- Surf  
\- Flamethrower  
\- Extrasensory/ Shadow Ball

Exploud is a decent Pokémon with stats that always tend to lean towards the
Spec. Attack. So Ah- Ha we have our first Special-Attacker! **Boomburst** is a
fantastic move with a base power of 140 and 210 with STAB. **Surf** is a good
move and is your means of water transportation. **Flamethrower** is a good
move that provides coverage and takes out the pesky grass types. The last slot
is a coverage holder. You can have **Extrasensory** to annihilate your
fighting type weakness (which you get through sneaking), or **Shadow Ball**
which you can use to take out Phoebe the second of the Elite 4.

Magnezone @ Magnet  
Ability: Sturdy  
\- Thunderbolt/ Thunder  
\- Flash Cannon  
\- Tri Attack  
\- Mirror Coat/ Rain Dance

Magnezone is a beast. His defenses aren't that bad so he can hold in there
longer than most and he has a really good Spec. Attack. **Tri Attack** is a
decent move and is really just a filler and **Flash Cannon** is your Steel
type STAB. **Thunderbolt** is a great move and fits better with the **Mirror
Coat** set. **Thunder** becomes totally OP when you add **Rain Dance** to it
and if you send out a Mega Swampert (Swolepert) his speed will double making
him just that much more over-powered.  
**P.S. If you choose not to evolve your Magneton and just give him the
Eviolite from route 123 he has less HP and less in both Attacks than
Magnezone, but every other stat gets better.**

Altaria @ Altarianite  
Ability: Natural Cure  > Pixilate  
\- Dragon Pulse  
\- Moon Blast  
\- Echoed Voice  
\- Fire Blast/ Flamethrower

Altaria is my favorite Drgon type you can obtain in the Hoenn (Besides
Flygon). This Pokémon is a beast in Battle and in the Contests. **Dragon
Pulse** is your main Dragon type move and is coverage against other Dragons.
**Moon Blast** is a great move as is, and just gets better when you mega
evolve. **Echoed Voice** was my Swablu's best buddy till it evolved and I just
couldn't part with it, not to mention how much better it gets wit Pixilate.
**Fire Blast** ,and **Flamethrower** are great moves, but I prefer **Fire
Blast** because of Contests.

I know, I know, no Pokémon has **Fly** , **Dive** , **Strength** or **Rock
Smash** and that's because I just waited to get the Eon Flute before doing any
Flying and the rest was just me switching out random HM Slaves and other
Pokémon to do what was necessary.

I hope this helped,

    
    
     ToatsMuhGoats
    

I have been experimenting with other Pokémon in my **Alpha Sapphire** , and
Gallade has been phenomenal. I kinda cheated a little and brought a Dawn Stone
over from my **Pokémon Y** version so I could have a Power-house early on and
he just rocks it. Here's his set-up:

Gallade @ Galladite  
Ability: Steadfast  > Inner Focus  
\- Psycho Cut  
\- Power-Up Punch  
\- Stone Edge/ Rockslide  
\- Brick Break/ Reflect

comments.content_original_markup:
Note: Many Pokemon in this team can mega evolve, its up to you who gets to do so.

Sceptile

  • Energy Ball
  • Dragon Claw
  • Earthquake
  • Rock Slide

I just love mega sceptile, he was my favorite starter from hoenn and still is. So Energy Ball is STAB, Dragon Claw is STAB as a mega and EQ and Rock Slide Covers all other weaknesses


Gyarados

  • Aqua Tail
  • Ice Fang
  • Chrunch
  • Earthquake

Another awesome Pokemon that can be mega evolved but remember only one Pokemon can mega evolve per fight. So Aqua Tail is STAB and the rest is coverage(Chrunch is STAB if mega)


Manetric

  • Thunderbolt
  • Flamethower
  • Volt Switch
  • Quick Attack / Thunder Wave

Thunderbolt is STAB, Flamethower is coverage, Volt Switch is a free switch and STAB, Quick attack is priority or Thunder wave for paralysis


Skarmory

  • Fly
  • Steel Wing
  • Night Slash
  • Spikes / Toxic

An awesome tank that can take physical hits awesomely, Fly and Steel Wing is STAB, Night Slash is coverage and Spikes or toxic are great status moves


Camerupt

  • Flamethrower
  • Earth Power
  • Solar Beam
  • Sunny Day / Yawn

A great Pokemon that can setup Sunny Day to boost STAB Flamethrower and make solar beam hit in one turn, Earth Power is coverage and Yawn is also an option


Gardevoir

  • Psychic
  • Moonblast
  • Shadow Ball/ Energy Ball
  • Thunderbolt / Calm Mind

A great Pokemon that adds to this teams diversity, Psychic and Moonblast is STAB, Shadow Ball and thunderbolt or Energy ball are coverage or Calm mind to setup

Hope you liked it :D

comments.content_original_markup:
This is for a standard team, so just pick Mudkip.
(Each Pokémon (except for Froslass) will have a HM, including Dig, just have a Pokémon in your PC knowing Dive)

1- Swampert

Item: Swampertite
Moves:
-Waterfall/Surf
-Brick Break/Hammer Arm
-Earthquake
-Sludge Wave

This guy has a very good attack, and has a good movepool. Plus, he has a Mega Evolution and an electric type immunity. Just, don't use against a grass type.

2- Mightyena

Item: BlackGlasses
Moves:
-Fire Fang
-Crunch
-Strength (HM)
-Iron Tail

Every move on this guy is very helpful, just make sure to get that Poochyena sticking out of the tall grass at the beginning.

3- Camerupt

Item: Cameruptite or Charcoal
-Flamethrower
-Rock Smash
-SolarBeam
-Iron Head

For all the people who just love Magcargo or Torkoal, I choose Camerupt due to type advantages.

4- Delcatty

Item: Silk Scarf
Moves:
Rain Dance
Water Pulse/Thunder
Dig
Zen Headbutt/Play Rough

This little guy is really good, and try to send out before Swampert so it can use it's mega ability (swift swim) Just make sure your Delcatty has Cute charm or Wonder Skin for its ability.

5- Tropius

Item: Miracle Seed
Moves
Dragon Pulse
Leaf Storm (Move Reminder)
Air Slash/Fly
Steel Wing

FEAR THE FLYING TREE

6- Froslass

Item: IDK
Moves
Wake Up-Slap
Ice Beam
Water Pulse
Shadow Ball

Creepy Pokedex entries aside, this Pokémon has great speed

Here's the team I played through Omega Ruby with! I'm about to challenge the E4 while writing this:


Cuddles (Swampert) @ Swampertite
Ability: Torrent > Swift Swim
-Waterfall
-Earthquake
-Surf
-Dive
I had to make him into a HM slave since I didn't have any other team members that could learn the water HM's and I didn't wanna get rid of a team member to have a slave. :/


Aki (Breloom) @ Silk Scarf
Ability: Poison Heal
-Drain Punch
-Seed Bomb
-Mach Punch
-Strength
After spending a while hunting, I found a Shroomish on DexNav and it had Drain Punch so that was cool :0 I gave her the Silk Scarf because I didn't have any other items.


Kiwi (Dodrio) @ Kings Rock
Ability: Run Away
-Pursuit
-Drill Peck
-Double Hit
-Fly
Kiwi is my flyer. He's probably one of my best team members due to his high Speed and Attack. He destroys everything.


Dollface (Banette) @ Banettite
Ability: Frisk > Prankster
-Calm Mind
-Shadow Ball
-Psychic
-Will-O-Wisp
I've always loved Banette so I decided to use one on this team! (I actually haven't went to get the Banettite yet due to laziness but I will in a moment...)


Lucy (Ninetales) @ Pecha Berry
Ability: Flash Fire
-Calm Mind
-Flamethrower
-Extrasensory
-Hex
I didn't have any items left so I just gave her a Pecha Berry. It was a pain to train her up as a Vulpix but it was totally worth it.


Vivi (Aggron) @ Lucky Egg
Ability: Rock Head
-Hone Claws
-Stone Edge
-Iron Tail
-Earthquake
This is the newest addition to the team. I just got her in Victory Road and after a little bit of training, she evolved. I gave her Hone Claws so she could land Iron Tail/Stone Edge more often.

I'm too lazy to put all the locations for the Pokémon, items and TM moves, so you can just go and look it up on the DB or something...idk.

comments.content_original_markup:
Team Preview:

(Pre-E4 - no items, moves or Pokémon only available in the Post-Game)
(This team is also based on a no-Exp. Share Playthrough)


Sceptile @ Sceptilinite (I SR'd for a Shiny - it was worth it lol)
Ability - Overgrow -> Lightning Rod

  • Giga Drain (Level 21 as Treecko)
  • Leaf Blade (Level 23)
  • Dragon Claw (TM02 - Meteor Falls)
  • Earthquake (TM26 - Seafloor Cavern)

While Treecko might not be the best starter available, it certainly can still hold his own against the Hoenn, especially because there is loads of water (insert IGN joke here). Treecko overall has pretty good stats, including great Special Attack and Speed and solid Attack, which are great combined with Sceptile's large movepool. They also have a Mega Evolution that makes that Dragon-type, which is pretty handy. Giga Drain is STAB and allows them to recover HP, Leaf Blade is agreat STAB move with a high critical hit chance, Dragon Claw is STAB if you decide to Mega Evolve, and Earthquake allows him to cover his Fire and Poison weaknesses. Rock Slide is another option and covers most of his weaknesses, but Earthquake is just overall better due to its higher power and accuracy.


Medicham @ Medichamite
Ability - Pure Power

  • Zen Headbutt (Move Reminder)
  • High Jump Kick (Level 28)
  • Ice Punch (Move Reminder)
  • Bulk Up (TM08 - Gift from Brawly) / Poison Jab (TM84 - Mirage Mountain)

I didn't really think of Medicham as something that was very worthwhile, but I tried it out as I wanted to use Azumarill, so I couyldn't have Gardevoir as they are both Psychic-type, and the road to Gallade is pretty tough on Kirlia, so I decided on Meditite, and I was pretty happy with my decision. Zen Headbutt is a decent STAB move with a decent flinch chance, High Jump Kick is a very powerful STAB move, but you will want to be careful using it, Ice Punch covers her Flying weakness, Bulk Up allows them to set up a possibly sweep, and Poison Jab covers her Fairy weakness. I decided to use Bulk Up as Poison Jab is pretty hard to get, and I simply didn't have the patience. But if you do, I would certainly recommend it. I would also recommend Mega Evolving Medicham more often than Sceptile, because Medicham is normally in bigger need of a buff to their stats.


Azumarill @ Quick Claw
Ability - Huge Power

  • Waterfall (HM05 - Gift from Wallace)
  • Play Rough (Level 25)
  • Bulldoze (TM78 - Mauville City Pokémart)
  • Surf (HM03 - Petalburg City after beating Norman) / Superpower (Level 46)

Ah, the evolution to the infamous Pikablu. I remember looking for one desperately for a Marill in HGSS when I was a kid, because I thought it was really cool, and when I finally got one, I hated it because I didn't understand how abilities work, but now I do, and this Pokémon takes great advantage of their great ability: Huge Power. Waterfall is your Water STAB and gets you up waterfalls, Play Rough is your Fairy STAB move, Bulldoze covers his weaknesses to Electric and Poison, Surf is because I was too lazy keep switching Pokémon so I had a different Surf-er, whereas, if you are patient enough, Superpower just gives him a little more coverage.


Magnezone @ Amulet Coin
Ability - Sturdy

  • Thunderbolt (TM24 - From Wattson after beating New Mauville side-quest)
  • Flash Cannon (Level 33)
  • Thunder Wave (Level 13)
  • Charge Beam (TM57 - Mauville City Pokémart)

Magnezone is easily one of the best, if not the best Electric-types in the game, only contended by Manectric. The Magnemite-line has great stats including a monstrous Special Attack stat and a great Defence stat, Steel-typing giving it good resistances, and pretty good STAB moves throughout the game. Thunderbolt is your Electric STAB move, Flash Cannon is your Steel STAB move, Thunder Wave cripples opponents and can help with Magnezone's bad speed, and Charge Beam can buff up their Special Attack so they can tear through teams.


Weezing @ Metronome
Ability - Levitate

  • Sludge Bomb (Level 34)
  • Flamethrower (TM35 - Victory Road)
  • Dark Pulse (TM97 - Team Magma/Aqua Hideout) / Shadow Ball (TM30 - Mt. Pyre)
  • Will-O-Wisp (TM61 - Mt. Pyre) / Infestation (TM83 - Sootopolis City) / Toxic (TM06 - Fiery Path)

Since I decided to play through the game with the Exp. Share turned off, I decided having bulky Pokémon would be a good idea, and while Weezing might not be as good as Aggron or Skarmory, I already had a Steel-type, I decided Weezing would be a good addition to the team. Weezing has pretty good moves, pretty good stats, and good defensive typing, which paired with Levitate, makes it a great Physical Wall. Sludge Bomb is STAB, Flamethrower is just for some coverage, Dark Pulse/Shadow Ball covers his only weakness: Psychic, and Will-O-Wisp/Infestation/Toxic is for chip damage, adding to his wall-y role.


Kecleon @ Expert Belt
Ability - Colour Change / Protean (H)

  • Slash (Level 25)
  • Shadow Sneak (Level 7 - May require Move Reminder)
  • Brick Break (TM31 - Sootopolis City)
  • Aerial Ace (TM40 - Mauville City Pokémart)

When I first got into Pokémon a while ago, Kecleon was my favourite Pokémon, because Chameleons were and still are my animals, so no doubt I loved Kecleon, especially since I Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Red Rescue Team as one of my first Pokémon games. Anyway, Kecleon may seem like an odd choice, but it is surprisingly solid. He has amazing Special Defence and good Attack, and a pretty great movepool. The moveset listed above was just the one I went with, but you have plenty of options for experimentation. Slash is STAB and has a high critical rate, Shadow Sneak gives him priority (and turns him into a Ghost-type with Protean, covering his Fighting weakness), and Brick Break and Aerial Ace are just for further coverage (or type-transformation with Protean). If you want Protean, catch the required Kecleon so you can DexNav for a Protean Kecleon, however if you don't have the time to get Protean, just catch the first one, and SR for a good nature. I would recommend Protean as it gives him STAB on every attack, but Colour Change is still useful in a lot of cases. Getting Protean was one of the things I was actually patient enough for.

comments.content_original_markup:
Sceptile
Ability: Overgrow -> Lightning Rod
Item: Wide Lens
Moves:
- Focus Blast : TM52 from Lilycove Department Store for 30k pokedollars
- Frenzy Plant : from Mauville move tutor
- Dragon Pulse : from Battle Resort move tutor for 12BP
- Earthquake : TM26 from Seafloor Cavern beneath Route 128

The first three are to utilize Sceptile's very high special attack. If you want to meg-evolve him for even more instead of the Wide Lens accuracy boost that works too. Earthquake is a strong filler move. I prefer Frenzy Plant to Leaf Storm because it has a higher base power, and so a higher chance to OHKO the opponent. Focus Blast and Dragon Pulse are coverage moves, with DP getting STAB from Mega-Sceptile.

Gyarados
Ability: Intimidate -> Mold Breaker
Item: Wacan Berry (or whatever you want)
Moves:
- Waterfall : HM05, you need it to complete the game
- Crunch : Level 41
- Ice Fang : Level 32
- Stone Edge : TM71 from Lilycove Department Store for 30k pokedollars

Waterfall and Crunch are physical STAB. You can use Aqua Tail instead of Waterfall if you'd like, but I like the flinch Waterfall can give you. Ice Fang is coverage against Grass, and Stone Edge against guys like Charizard. You can mega-evolve it if you'd like, but personally I think other mega-evolutions are much better choices that Gyarados'.

Aggron
Ability: Rock Head -> Filter
Item: Assault Vest
Moves:
- Iron Tail : Level 35
- Stone Edge : see above
- Double Edge : Level 45
- Brick Break : TM31 in Sootopolis City

Iron Tail is STAB anti-Fairy, Stone Edge is also STAB. Double Edge is general coverage with a very strong move, especially given the Rock Head ability. Brick Break is a filler, taking advantage of the Fighting type's usefulness. The Assault Vest makes Aggron more of a tank, and I don't use status moves anyway. They're pointless in-game. Mega-Aggron is a less balanced tank, which is more applicable in some situations.

Gardevoir
Ability: Trace -> Pixilate
Item: nothing/anything
Moves:
- Shadow Ball : TM30 at Mt. Pyre
- Moonblast : Level 62 or Move Reminder in Fallarbor Town
- Thunderbolt : TM24 after New Mauville quest
- Psychic : Level 31

Psychic is STAB. Moonblast is STAB and anti-Dragon. Shadow Ball covers against Ghost and other Psychics. Thunderbolt is a strong electric move that is helped by Gardevoir's high SpA, especially helpful against Wallace and Steven's Skarmory. Gardevoir doesn't have any great abilities, but on a rare occasion Trace can help in some cool ways.

Heracross
Ability: Guts -> Skill Link
Item: Heracronite
Moves:
- Earthquake : see above
- Megahorn : Level 37
- Close Combat : Level 43
- Bullet Seed : Move Reminder in Fallarbor Town

You have to mega-evolve Heracross. You just have to. I mean, just look at that 185 base Att. As good as any other Pokemon are, Mega-Heracross is a flat out boss. Megahorn and Close Combat are really strong STAB. With Skill Link, Bullet Seed becomes one of the best Grass-type moves out there, and Earthquake is a regular. Remember: Mega-evolve Heracross at all times!!

Ninetales
Ability: Flash Fire
Item: whatever you want (I sometimes use Choice Specs)
Moves:
- Fire Blast : TM38 at Lilycove Department Store for 30k pokedollars
- Solar Beam : TM22 at the Safari Zone
- Dark Pulse : TM97 at the Team Magma/Aqua Hideout
- Psyshock : TM03 at Pacifidlog Town

Is a TM slave a thing? Ninetales is the butt of my team, but still fills a key role. I call it a SpA Sweeper Specialist. When theres a particularly annoying Pokemon that I don't want to waste one of my key troops on, I roll out Ninetales to hand out some super-effective mojo. Of course this doesn't always work, but the moveset I run on Ninetales highlights its strengths and covers my team pretty well. The Flash Fire ability is underrated, but if you can pick up Drought do so. Really helps with Fire Blast and Solar Beam.

You might be wondering why so few HMs. I don't like putting HMs on my main party Pokemon, so when I need an HM I'll switch someone (probably Nintales) out for an HM slave like Linoone or Sharpedo. Otherwise, this team will straight up scrape anyone who tries to beat you. (Assuming you don't throw out Mega-Sceptile in front of Glacia or something)

\- **Crunch** : Level 41  
\- **Ice Fang** : Level 32  
\- **Stone Edge** : TM71 from Lilycove Department Store for 30k pokedollars

Waterfall and Crunch are physical STAB. You can use Aqua Tail instead of
Waterfall if you'd like, but I like the flinch Waterfall can give you. Ice
Fang is coverage against Grass, and Stone Edge against guys like Charizard.
You can mega-evolve it if you'd like, but personally I think other mega-
evolutions are much better choices that Gyarados'.

* * *

**Aggron**  
Ability: Rock Head - > Filter  
Item: Assault Vest  
Moves:  
\- **Iron Tail** : Level 35  
\- **Stone Edge** : see above  
\- **Double Edge** : Level 45  
\- **Brick Break** : TM31 in Sootopolis City

Iron Tail is STAB anti-Fairy, Stone Edge is also STAB. Double Edge is general
coverage with a very strong move, especially given the Rock Head ability.
Brick Break is a filler, taking advantage of the Fighting type's usefulness.
The Assault Vest makes Aggron more of a tank, and I don't use status moves
anyway. They're pointless in-game. Mega-Aggron is a less balanced tank, which
is more applicable in some situations.

* * *

**Gardevoir**  
Ability: Trace - > Pixilate  
Item: nothing/anything  
Moves:  
\- **Shadow Ball** : TM30 at Mt. Pyre  
\- **Moonblast** : Level 62 or Move Reminder in Fallarbor Town  
\- **Thunderbolt** : TM24 after New Mauville quest  
\- **Psychic** : Level 31

Psychic is STAB. Moonblast is STAB and anti-Dragon. Shadow Ball covers against
Ghost and other Psychics. Thunderbolt is a strong electric move that is helped
by Gardevoir's high SpA, especially helpful against Wallace and Steven's
Skarmory. Gardevoir doesn't have any great abilities, but on a rare occasion
Trace can help in some cool ways.

* * *

**Heracross**  
Ability: Guts - > Skill Link  
Item: Heracronite  
Moves:  
\- **Earthquake** : see above  
\- **Megahorn** : Level 37  
\- **Close Combat** : Level 43  
\- **Bullet Seed** : Move Reminder in Fallarbor Town

You have to mega-evolve Heracross. You just have to. I mean, just look at that
185 base Att. As good as any other Pokemon are, Mega-Heracross is a flat out
boss. Megahorn and Close Combat are really strong STAB. With Skill Link,
Bullet Seed becomes one of the best Grass-type moves out there, and Earthquake
is a regular. Remember: Mega-evolve Heracross at all times!!

* * *

**Ninetales**  
Ability: Flash Fire  
Item: whatever you want (I sometimes use Choice Specs)  
Moves:  
\- **Fire Blast** : TM38 at Lilycove Department Store for 30k pokedollars  
\- **Solar Beam** : TM22 at the Safari Zone  
\- **Dark Pulse** : TM97 at the Team Magma/Aqua Hideout  
\- **Psyshock** : TM03 at Pacifidlog Town

Is a TM slave a thing? Ninetales is the butt of my team, but still fills a key
role. I call it a SpA Sweeper Specialist. When theres a particularly annoying
Pokemon that I don't want to waste one of my key troops on, I roll out
Ninetales to hand out some super-effective mojo. Of course this doesn't always
work, but the moveset I run on Ninetales highlights its strengths and covers
my team pretty well. The Flash Fire ability is underrated, but if you can pick
up Drought do so. Really helps with Fire Blast and Solar Beam.

* * *

You might be wondering why so few HMs. I don't like putting HMs on my main
party Pokemon, so when I need an HM I'll switch someone (probably Nintales)
out for an HM slave like Linoone or Sharpedo. Otherwise, this team will
straight up scrape anyone who tries to beat you. (Assuming you don't throw out
Mega-Sceptile in front of Glacia or something)

comments.content_original_markup:
Finally decided to answer a team question (no pics sorry)

Pokemon #1- Sceptile
Sceptile @ Sceptilite
-Giga Drain
-Dual Chop
-Leaf Storm/Leaf Blade
-Focus Blast/Brick Break

Alright, so this will be your starter obviously. You could go mixed or choose Leaf Blade in place of Giga Drain and run Brick Break in place of Leaf Storm and go physical, although his base attack isn't very great compared to his sp.atk. Overall, great Pokemon and a big help at the last gym.
___

Pokemon #2 - Exploud
Exploud @ Leftovers/Shell Bell
-Boomburst
-Flamethrower
-Ice Beam
-(insert a move of choice here)

So this comes fairly early on in the game. For Boomburst, use a Heart Scale or just level up to level 58. If you can't get it, Hyper Voice is the next best bet. Ice Beam and Flamethrower are fairly late in the game, but you could wait or substitute with another move of your choice.
___
Pokemon #3 - Linoone
Linoone @ any item
-Strength
-Surf
-Cut
-Rock Smash

The HM slave. Need I say more?
___
Pokemon #4 - Swellow
Swellow @ anything (doesn't matter for this one)
-Return
-Fly
-Steel Wing
-Roost

Found at the route after Rustboro and Petalburg Woods, Swellow can be quite useful in battle and as a flyer. Great speed, but sadly only great thing about it. Sub-par attack at base 85 (I think)
and very bad defenses. A mega evolution is what it needs ;~;
___
Pokemon #5 - Sharpedo
Sharpedo @ Sharpedonite
-Waterfall
-Crunch
-Ice Beam
-(insert any move of choice here)

Really, just here for raw power and Waterfall. Also useful against Steven's Metagross.
___
Pokemon #6 - Flygon
Flygon @ Yache Berry (be careful 1 time use)
-Earthquake
-Dragon Claw
-Stone Edge
-U-Turn/Roost

Best part? Earthquake is through Heart Scale as well! Finally an early quaker! Great Pokemon who also gets Fly and Strength.
___

Hope this team helps!

comments.content_original_markup:
Usually every team has an HM slave, but this one doesn't. You spread the roles evenly through the team. 'Tis optional which Pokemon you give the HMs to but basically these are the Pokemon that got me through the whole game (Delta Episode as well) in a few days. Mightyena is optional and I traded to get 3 starters in one team (originally 4) so it may not be easy to get but it works. Anyway here it is:

Blaziken @Blazikenite
Ability: Blaze (Speed Boost when mega evolved)
-Brave Bird
-Flare Blitz
-Sky Uppercut
-Blaze Kick/Stone Edge
(Can also temporarily have cut as a Combusken/Torchic, I recommend removing it though)

I choose Torchic as my starter whenever I restart this game because Mega Blaziken is such a beast. Brave bird and Flare Blitz are to deal with Psychic and Flying types (if you aren't running stone edge) and Special Walls. With STAB, Flare blitz becomes 180 power, Sky uppercut and Blaze Kick both become 127.5 power (rounded to 125). Stone edge isn't reliable accuracy-wise but is a very powerful counter for flying.

Gardevoir @Gardevoirite (Mega stone obtainable after delta episode)
Ability: Synchronize (Pixilate when mega evolved)
-Psychic/Psyshock
-Calm Mind
-Magical Leaf (Optional)
-Hyper voice (Turns into fairy type and gets boost with mega gardevoir's ability)

Mega Gardevoir with this set is an all-around beast. All moves are powered up by Calm Mind's Sp.Atk boost. Magical leaf is what I used the whole game through, but wasn't that reliable because of the 60 power. I would like ideas for other possible moves, if anyone has any. Mega Gardevoir also has the Ability Pixilate, which makes all normal type moves Fairy Type AND gives them a 30% boost which brings Hyper Voice to 175.5 power or 220.5 if it's super effective which is insane!

Mightyena @Choice Scarf/Quick Claw
Ability: Intimidate
-Ice Fang
-Crunch
-Take down
-Assurance/Thief/Rock Smash

Mightyena is insanely strong with the STAB Crunch but the other moves are slightly disappointing. I easily wipe Pheobe of the E4's team with the Crunch. Not sure of any replacements, but I am thinking Thief/Snarl would be good to replace assurance because both the items on Mightyena increase speed, making Assurance practically useless.

Torterra @ Soft Sand/Miracle Seed/Yache Berry
Ability: Overgrow
-Wood Hammer
-Crunch
-Razor Leaf/Synthesis
-Earthquake

Nothing much to say about this set except that it is your best bet against Electric types.

Feraligatr @Sea Incense/Wacan Berry
Ability: Torrent
-Crunch
-Strength
-Aqua Tail/Hydro Pump
-Waterfall

Feraligatr's Attack Stat is higher than his Sp.Atk stat so I would recommend running Aqua Tail over Hydro Pump unless you are confident enough to deal with the accuracy and have a +Sp.Atk nature. Strength and Crunch are optional, if you find anything better please tell me but waterfall is a must. I'm sure it is the 2nd strongest physical water move behind aqua tail.

Ludicolo @Amulet Coin/Mystic Water/ Miracle Seed
Ability: Rain Dish
-Fake Out/Giga Drain
-Ice Beam/Blizzard
-Surf/Hydro Pump
-Rain dance

Ludicolo is usually called a useless Pokemon or unworthy or even being a Pokemon, but this set for Ludicolo works well. As flying is a big weakness for the team (Torterra, Ludicolo and Blaziken and even sometimes Gardevoir because of Crobat), I have given Ludicolo ice beam. I do recommend it over blizzard as blizzard has terrible accuracy. My Ludicolo is lvl88 and currently packs fake out, ice beam, surf and rain dance. Easily destroys some of the E4's beasts like Salamence, Altaria, Shiftry and Mandibuzz with a simple Fake Out/Ice beam combo or you can take care of Pokemon like Pheobe's Chandelure and Mega Sableye with a Rain dance/Surf combo.

Thank you for reading this... if you did or No thanks for skipping to the end. Anyway, hope this helps with anyone currently team building.

comments.content_original_markup:
This is the team I'm currently using to complete Omega Ruby.

Blaziken@Blazinite
Ability: Blaze (unless you go through the trouble of obtaining speed boost)
-Blaze Kick (can swap out for something like Flare Blitz for competitive if you like)
-Bulk Up
-Sky Uppercut
-(I normally use something like Double Team to go with my Bulk Up, but basically a filler. Could also use Sunny Day to up Blaze Kick and help Shiftry)

Shiftry@Expert Belt
Ability: Chlorophyll
-Leaf Blade/Leaf Storm (I personally prefer Leaf Blade)
-Faint Attack (Like the no miss bonus)
- Solar Beam/Hurricane (for against the pesky bugs if you plan to leave Shiftry out instead of swapping)
-Sunny Day

Crobat@Black Sludge
Ability: Infiltrator
-Cross Poison
-Fly/Brave Bird/(or Acrobatics if you don't want to use an item for even more damage)
-Toxic
-Confuse Ray (or your choise. Filler mostly)

Milotic@Leftovers
Ability: Competitive/Marvel Scale
-Aqua Ring
-Rain Dance
-Hydro Pump
-Ice Beam (to deal with Dragons)

Rhyperior@Leftovers/Focus Sash
Ability: Solid Rock
-Earthquake
-Rock Wrecker
-Protect (to prevent damage every two turns and let Leftovers replenish some HP)
-Megahorn/Hammer Arm/Horn Drill

Now I'm using Grumpig as my 6th Pokemon mostly because I hate how they 'changed' some Pokemon types to Fairy. For my Physic type I would normally choose Gallade, however, I already have a fighting type, Blaziken. If not for the change in Gardevoir's type, I would use her. But I greatly dislike how she's part Fairy now. But she would be way better than Grumpig, especially with the Fairy bonus.

Gardevoir@Gardenite
Ability: Telepathy
-Moonblast
-Hypnosis
-Psychic/Calm Mind
-Dream Eater/Calm Mind
^you can use both Psychic and Dream Eater since her Sp. Attack is already really high.

I had a blast using the three starter Pokemon right out of the gate utilizing the Pokemon Bank.

Torchic: Transferred via Pokemon Bank at the story's beginning

Blaziken:
Flare Blitz

This is my ORAS team:

Serperior @ Miracle Seed

Ability : Contrary

Leaf Storm : Good STAB, plus SAtt. is Raised by 2

Dragon Pulse : Great dragon type move

Cut : To get past Trees

Aerial Ace : Never misses

Altaria @ Leftovers

Ability : Sincere Grace

Dragon Pulse : Excellent STAB

Flamethrower : Great Fire type move

Fly : To get to places faster

Steel Wing : To get past Fairy Types

Charizard @ Charizardite X

Ability : Blaze > Tough Claws

Dragon Claw : Great STAB

Flare Blitz : Excellent STAB, but takes damage though

Steel Wing : Get Past Fairies

Brick Break : Breaks Reflect, and Light Screen

Samurott @ Focus Sash

Ability : Shell Armor

False Swipe : Lowers Pokémon's HP down to 1

Surf : You need to surf in ORAS

Waterfall : Good STAB, and climb waterfalls

Dive : Need to dive, and does good damage

Porygon - Z @ Life Orb

Ability : Adaptability

Nasty Plot : Raises Special Attack by 2 Stages

Tri Attack : Chance to burn, paralyze, or freeze opponent, and great STAB

Thunderbolt : Takes out flying, and water

Ice Beam : Takes out flying, ground, and grass types

Eelektross @ Muscle Band

Ability : Levitate

Wild Charge : Wonderful STAB, but takes Recoil Damage

Crunch : Takes care of Ground

Dragon Claw : Takes out Mega Charizard X

Crush Claw : Chance to lower target's defense by 1 stage

comments.content_original_markup:
Hi! so I've used a pretty similar setup about 5-6 times since Sapphire originally came out, but playing Omega Ruby & Alpha(each once) has changed my mind recently.
(Foreword: So , I have a soft spot for grass types, and i'd usually go with Sceptile before in Gen 3, but I used Blaziken most recently, so ill go with that setup.)

1- Starter: Blaziken

Moves:
1- Sky Uppercut (Fighting)
2- Aerial Ace (Flying)
3- Blast Burn (Fire)
4-Fire Pledge (Fire)
His(or her in my case) Movesets cover every area you would want, with the move to take advantage of most Pokemon's weakness, and it can even learn thunderpunch by tutor to offset water's super effectiveness.
2-Armaldo (yes you should really get anorith as soon as you get the fossil, its not really out of your way if you take rusturf)

Moves:
1- X-Scissor (Bug)
2- Earthquake (Ground)
3- Stone Edge (Rock)
4- Rock Blast (Rock)
I really like having at least 1 good bug attack, 1 ground and maybe rock, well this Pokemon can do that, and brine(water) if you want a counter for other rock/ground Pokemon also. It can kinda be half tank, half attacker.

3- Metagross

Moves:
1- Meteor Mash (Steel)
2- Flash Cannon (Steel)
3- Psychic (Psychic)
4- ShadowBall (Ghost)
(Since you dont get Beldum until after the elite 4, I personally use Latias/Latios until I get Beldum as my Psychic type. For Latias I use Shadow Ball(ghost,) Dragon Pulse (dragon,) and Draco Meteor (Dragon, learned from tutor in sootopolis city)

4- Gyarados

Moves:
1- Surf (Water)
2- Hydro Pump (Water)
3-Dragon Pulse (Dragon)
4- Dark Pulse or Crunch
(Mega- Gyarados is Dragon/Dark type, so you'll definitely want a dark move for STAB bonuses) As far as replacements, Ive Used Walrein twice and hes a monster, and Milotic as borderline OP, and both are SO easy to evolve now with the new EXP share.

5-Shiftry

Moves:
1- Leaf Blade (Grass)
2- Leaf Storm (Grass)
3- Extrasensory (Psychic)
4- Dark Pulse
(Again, Shiftry is a Dark type so you'll want to keep a dark move for STAB. Replacements could easily be Sceptile,Tropius, Gloom (Fairy type is useful) or Breloom (fighting combo is helpfu.l)

6- Flygon

Moves:
1- Earthquake (Ground)
2- Earth Power (Ground
3- Crunch (Dark, have to wait a few levels with vibriva)
4- Dragon Rush (Dragon)
An all-around good Pokemon. Doesnt excel too much in one area, but we'll worth raising. Can be swapped with salamence, or scrapped altogether for an electric Pokemon since Gyarados has dragon, and Dark moves (along with shiftry)

In Omega Ruby iv been using some legendaries, but for the most part this is the team ive been running, (Im CLEARLY all special attack/kill em fast huh? lol)

comments.content_original_markup:
I went with a team I tried to balance with as many types as I could get, along with some high base stats. Moves are after getting rid of most HM's for E4 and Champ.

Sceptile - Grass (MSceptile - Grass/Dragon)
Ability - Overgrow (MSceptile - Lightning Rod)
Moveset - Leaf Storm, Leaf Blade, X-Scissor, Dragon Claw - can swap Earthquake in for X-Scissor for fire types
Overall, just my favorite of the starters. Type disadvantage is an issue with fire types but can change one move to Earthquake or use Aggron for Surf.

Gardevoir - Psychic/Fairy
Ability - Synchronize
Moveset - Moonblast, Magical Leaf, Draining Kiss, Shadow Ball
Nice dual type Pokemon. Deadly against dragon types and can use Shadow Ball on fellow psychics. Magical Leaf good for rock types and water types.

Aggron - Steel/Rock (MAggron - Steel)
Ability - Rock Head
Moveset - Double Edge, Iron Head, Earthquake, Surf
Rock Head is a must for Double Edge. Really useful to be able to use that powerful attack and have no recoil. Surf is good for dealing with pesky fire types. Same with Earthquake.

Crobat - Poison/Flying
Ability - Inner Focus
Moveset - Acrobatics, Cross Poison, X-Scissor, Dark Pulse
Can deal with psychics with Dark Pulse and X-Scissor. Acrobatics is deadly when not holding an item.

Crawdaunt - Water/Dark
Ability - Shell Armor
Moveset - Sludge Wave, Ice Beam, Dark Pulse, Crabhammer
Fairies are no problem with Sludge Wave. Sludge Wave also good for the grass types, along with Ice Beam. Crabhammer just powerful.

Flygon - Ground/Dragon
Ability - Levitate
Moveset - Boomburst, Flamethrower, Steel Wing, Dragon Claw
Don't evolve Vibrava till level 47 so it can learn Boomburst. Flamethrower is good for ice types and Steel Wing for the fairies.

comments.content_original_markup:
This is a very balanced one around Mudkip.

Swampert@Swampertite
Ability: Torrent

  • Waterfall
  • Earthquake
  • Hammer Arm
  • Ice Punch

Waterfall and Earthquake are STAB and accurate. Hammer Arm for coverage and Ice Punch takes care of the 4x grass weakness.

Linoone@None
Ability: Pickup

  • Cut
  • Surf
  • Strength
  • Rock Smash

While he is an HM slave, I do recommend you use him in battle as well. When your at the elite four you should forget his HM's though and replace them with more useful coverage moves like Thunderbolt, Ice Beam, Shadow Ball and Return for example. And Pickup is super useful as well, hence why he has no item.

Roserade@Miracle Seed
Ability: Natural Cure

  • Leech Seed
  • Toxic
  • Shadow Ball
  • Giga Drain

Leech Seed and Toxic wears the opponent down. She can restore health with Leech Seed and Giga Drain aswell. Giga Drain is also STAB and Shadow Ball is for type coverage.

Ninetales@Charcoal
Ability: Flash Fire

  • Nasty Plot
  • Will-o-Wisp
  • Energy Ball
  • Flamethrower

Nasty Plot to sharply raise Sp. Attack and Will-o-Wisp to inflict burns and take less physical damage. Energy Ball covers all weaknesses and Flamethrower is solid STAB.

Raichu@Magnet
Ability: Static

  • Nuzzle
  • Quick Attack
  • Thunderbolt
  • Grass Knot

Nuzzle is simply a better version of Thunder Wave, dealing damage as well. Quick attack for priority and Thunderbolt is STAB. Grass Knot covers Ground types.

Skarmory@Leftovers
Ability: Sturdy

  • Fly

comments.content_original_markup:
Treecko chosen
Electrode (Soundproof): Hyper Beam/Rollout, Electro Ball, Thunderbolt, Magnet Rise
Mega Altaria (Pixilate): Fly, Draco Meteor, Take Down, Dragon Claw
Camerupt (Solid Rock): Eruption, Earth Power, Rock Slide, Flamethrower
Sandslash (Sand Veil): Sandstorm, Earthquake, Stone Edge, Swords Dance
Crawdaunt (Hyper Cutter): Surf, Ice Beam, Crunch, Crabhammer
Sceptile (Overgrow): Dual Chop, Energy Ball, Leaf Blade, Swords Dance

Torchic chosen
Magnezone (Magnet Pull): Thunderbolt, Tri Attack, Flash Cannon, Thunder Wave
Beautifly (Swarm): Quiver Dance, Energy Ball, Psychic, Bug Buzz
Flygon: Fly, Earthquake, Rock Slide, Dragon Claw
Mega Sharpedo: Surf, Ice Fang, Crunch, Waterfall
Gardevoir (Synchronize): Moonblast, Shadow Ball, Energy Ball, Psychic
Blaziken (Blaze): Flamethrower/Overheat, Sky Uppercut, Bulk Up, Blaze Kick

Mudkip chosen
Cosplay Pikachu (Static): Icicle Crash, Thunderbolt, Iron Tail, Brick Break
Roselia/Roserade (Poison Point): Energy Ball, Sludge Bomb, Dazzling Gleam, Safeguard
Salamence (Intimidate): Flamethrower, Fly, Dragon Claw, Crunch
Heracross (Guts): Megahorn, Earthquake, Close Combat, Shadow Claw
Aggron (Sturdy): Hone Claws, Earthquake, Rock Slide, Iron Head
Mega Swampert (Torrent): Surf, Ice Beam, Earthquake, Stone Edge

Now, here's the reasoning behind all my suggestions!
With Treecko, you need anti-poison, anti-bug, anti-fire, and anti-ice strategies. Since you have an actually good grass type, selecting your electric type really isn't that important, so you could just teach Thunderbolt to a non-Electric type. Mega Altaria will serve as your flying type. I equipped her with mostly physical attacks because they are not affected by Draco Meteor. Since Pixilate converts moves to Fairy, Altaria's Take Down gets STAB. Camerupt is our fire type, strong against many of Metagross's attacks. So, he'll be perfect to use in the final battle against Steven - and in a team replete with medium slow and slow levelling rates, having a medium fast Pokemon is great. Sandslash is our ground type, and supposed to balance out against most fire and poison types. Crawdaunt is our water type. Give him Surf for HM and Ice Beam for Dragon types. He learns Crunch - teach it to him at all costs due to both STAB and coverage against Phoebe's ghost Pokemon. And lastly, we have Sceptile. The good thing is that he has wonderful Sp Attack and decent attack. The problem is that most of his coverage moves are physical, so you just have to make the most of it with Dual Chop, Leaf Blade, and Swords Dance.

With Torchic, you need water, grass, and dark to deal with rock, ground, fairy, water, and psychic. It's also incredibly important who you use as your electric type. This makes Magnezone a perfect fit. Flygon triples as a rock type (okay, he's really a ground type), a Flyer, and a dragon type. Give him Fly, Dragon Claw, Earthquake, and Rock Slide (no need for Crunch, and you'll see why). Sharpedo has extremely good attack (despite his pathetic poor defenses), and I would recommend teaching it Surf since it isn't too bad of a move for his special attack. Beautifly is here to serve as a high-powered special attacker, and so is Gardevoir. Both Beautifly and Gardevoir will learn Energy Ball as both these guys have better coverage moves than grass types. And even though Beautifly is really weak to Rock types, it has the speed and special attack to OHKO most of em in one hit. And I'm teaching Blaziken one special move because Metagross won't go down in one hit even from a supereffective physical move. I also threw Beautifly in here to speed up the leveling process.

With Mudkip, your primary concern is grass. So, a poison type could work well - enter Roselia and Sludge Bomb. She doubles as a grass type. Salamence is probably your best bet here as a fire type (Even though it's dragon and flying) since he's so versatile. A Flamethrower from Salamence will do lots of damage to Steven's team. The problem with him is that he appears so late in the game, but he's worthwhile all the same. Heracross is quite useful as a fighting type due to power and speed. Aggron is here to neutralize weaknesses to grass, and give him Sturdy so he can survive Focus Blast or Earth Power. Cosplay Pikachu is here because you get him quite early in the game, and although he can't evolve or anything, he gets a special move (which gets powered up by a free Light Ball on route 120). But this move HAS to be Icicle Crash to deal with ground - otherwise you may as well teach him a regular move. And lastly, Swampert. Mega Evolve him so that his Surf and Ice Beam attacks actually do damage. I normally would be suggesting Ice Punch and Aqua Tail instead of Surf and Ice Beam, but you can't get Ice Punch before the Pokemon League, so Ice Beam will have to do for now. Happy playing!!!

comments.content_original_markup:
Sceptile @ Sceptilite/Miracle Seed
Trait - Overgrow > Lightningrod

  • Leaf Storm
  • Leaf Blade
  • Dragon Claw
  • Rock Slide

Leaf Storm is a very strong move and the Sp. A drop isn't a problem as this set is mainly physical, Leaf Blade and Dragon Claw (when mega) are both STAB and Rock Slide cover fire, ice, flying and bug and has a decent flinch chance.

Gallade @ Galladite/Expert Belt
Trait - Steadfast > Inner Focus

  • Brick Break/Close Combat
  • Night Slash
  • Ice Punch/Thunder Punch
  • Psycho Cut

Both Close Combat and Brick Break are useful. Close Combat is stronger with less PP and an additional effect of lowering both defences while Brick Break breaks screens but is less powerful but will still do good damage with high base Attack. Night Slash is ghost type coverage and Ice Punch/Thunder Punch are flying type coverage.

Tentacruel @ Black Sludge
Trait - Clear Body

  • Surf
  • Sludge Wave
  • Waterfall
  • Ice Beam

Surf is needed for the story and is STAB, Sludge wave has a poison chance and is STAB, Waterfall is also needed for the Story and is STAB with a flinch chance and Ice Beam has a freeze chance and is ground coverage. (Dive is also an alternative for Waterfall and is needed for the story but I recommend Waterfall)

Altaria @ Altarianite/Leftovers
Trait - Natural Cure > Pixilate

  • Fly
  • Flamethrower
  • Dragon Pulse
  • Return/Moonblast

Fly is useful for getting around and is STAB, Flamethrower has a burn chance and covers ice, Dragon Pulse is STAB and use return if you are going to Mega Evolve as it gets STAB from pixilate but if you don't Mega Evolve use Moonblast.

Camerupt @ Cameruptite/Charcoal
Trait - Solid Rock > Sheer Force

  • Flamethrower
  • Earthquake
  • Rock Slide
  • Eruption

Flamethrower has a burn chance and is STAB, Earthquake is STAB, Rock Slide has a flinch chance (Rock Slide could be swapped for a status move moves like Curse, Amnesia or Yawn for example) and Eruption is good for doing big damage when Camerupt hasn't taken any damage himself.

Magnezone @ Magnet/Metal Coat
Trait - Sturdy

  • Charge Beam/Metal Sound
  • Thunderbolt
  • Thunder Wave/Tri-Attack
  • Flash Cannon

Charge Beam has a huge chance of raising it's already very high Sp. A but Metal Sound harshly lowers the opponents Sp. D with less accuracy though. Thunder Wave makes up for the speed that he lacks but Tri-Attack has a chance to either burn, freeze or paralyse the opponent. Flash Cannon has a chance of decreasing the opponents Sp.D and has STAB and Thunderbolt is STAB.

comments.content_original_markup:
Team Preview: Swampert, Gardevoir, Hariyama, Crobat, Manetric, Absol


Swampert (Mudkipz) @ Swampertite/Macho Brace
Ability: Torrent > Swift Swim

  • Surf/Hammer Arm/Rock Slide/Rain Dance
  • Waterfall
  • Earthquake
  • Ice Beam

Swampert is a beast both Offensively and Defensively because of it's excellent typing and good stats, and it helps in many parts of the game like with Wattson and Flannery for example. Surf is important for the story but his other moves provide coverage and are also physical and Rain Dance activates Swift Swim in his mega form. Waterfall gains STAB as does Earthquake and Ice Beam takes care of Swampert's only weakness; Grass.


Gardevoir (Athena) @ Gardevoirite/Life Orb
Ability: Synchronise > Pixilate

  • Psychic
  • Shadow Ball
  • Moonblast
  • Calm Mind/Focus Blast/Thunderbolt

Gardevoir is a very good Pokémon with a large movepool and very high Special stats. Gardevoir also does very well against the evil teams as it can easily beat Poison and Dark types. Psychic and Moonblast do heaps with STAB and Gardevoir's high Sp. A and Shadow Ball is for coverage. Calm Mind increases Sp. A and Sp. D making Gardevoir a monster and Focus Blast and Thunderbolt are for coverage.


Hariyama (Yokozuna) @ Leftovers
Ability: Thick Fat

  • Close Combat
  • Bulk Up
  • Stone Edge
  • Earthquake

Hariyama, just like Swampert, is very good on offence and defence and helps out on important parts of the game like Norman, Glacia and of course Steven. Close Combat will deal huge damage but drops it's defeces by one stage but Hariyama's huge HP blanks that and will do even more after Bulk Up raising his Attack and Defence. Stone Edge and Earthquake are for coverage and are overall great moves.


Crobat (Acrobat) @ Black Sludge
Ability: Inner Focus

  • Cross Poison
  • Fly
  • Steel Wing
  • U-Turn/X-Scissor/Roost

Crobat is a very fast and well-rounded Pokémon who is definately worth the struggle of Zubat, while Crobat isn't super-useful against the Gyms, E4 and Champion, it is still a good Pokémon non the less. Cross Poison has a high Critical Hit ratio and a poison chance which is handy and also gains STAB as does Fly which also gets you around the reigon. Steel Wing is for coverage as are X-Scissor and U-Turn and Roost heals half of Crobat's max HP but it loses it's Flying type until the end of the turn. Also it's nickname, Acrobat, A-Crobat. LOLOLOLOL.


Manectric (Raiju) @ Manecricite/Metronome
Ability: Lightning Rod > Intimidate

  • Volt Switch
  • Thunderbolt
  • Flamethrower
  • Double Team

Manectric is a very fast and very strong but unfortunately lacks bulk however getting Intimidate as he Mega Evolves does make up for this and he is usefull for a few battles, mainly Winona and Wallace. Volt Switch allows a free hit before you swap instead of just swapping out and Thunderbolt will be your main STAB with a paralyse chance. Flamethrower is for coverage and is a good move and Double Team will increase evasiveness which can allow free turns and with Manectric's high speed it'll likely be able to get at least one off.


Absol (Eclipse) @ Absolite/Muscle Band
Ability: Super Luck > Magic Bounce

  • Swords Dance
  • Night Slash
  • Psycho Cut
  • Rock Slide/Aerial Ace/X-Scissor/Shadow Claw

Absol is definitely a glass cannon having very small bulk but very high attack but if used in the right circumstances and it will be a force to be reckoned with. Swords Dance pretty much means you are ready to sweep but having low defences makes this a risky but satisfying play. Night Slash is main STAB and has a high Critical Hit ratio combined with Super luck this move will be a critical almost all the time, same goes for Psycho Cut which is for coverage. All the other moves are for coverage.

game%20team%20for%20Omega%20Ruby%20and%20Alpha%20Sapphire%3F%20\(page%203\)%20-%20Poke%CC%81Base%20Poke%CC%81mon%20Answers_files/image_011.png)  
**Hariyama (Yokozuna)** @ Leftovers  
Ability: Thick Fat

  * Close Combat 
  * Bulk Up 
  * Stone Edge 
  * Earthquake 

_Hariyama, just like Swampert, is very good on offence and defence and helps
out on important parts of the game like Norman, Glacia and of course Steven.
Close Combat will deal huge damage but drops it's defeces by one stage but
Hariyama's huge HP blanks that and will do even more after Bulk Up raising his
Attack and Defence. Stone Edge and Earthquake are for coverage and are overall
great moves._

![](What%20is%20a%20good%20in-
game%20team%20for%20Omega%20Ruby%20and%20Alpha%20Sapphire%3F%20\(page%203\)%20-%20Poke%CC%81Base%20Poke%CC%81mon%20Answers_files/image_010.png)  
**Crobat (Acrobat)** @ Black Sludge  
Ability: Inner Focus

  * Cross Poison 
  * Fly 
  * Steel Wing 
  * U-Turn/X-Scissor/Roost 

_Crobat is a very fast and well-rounded Pokémon who is definately worth the
struggle of Zubat, while Crobat isn't super-useful against the Gyms, E4 and
Champion, it is still a good Pokémon non the less. Cross Poison has a high
Critical Hit ratio and a poison chance which is handy and also gains STAB as
does Fly which also gets you around the reigon. Steel Wing is for coverage as
are X-Scissor and U-Turn and Roost heals half of Crobat's max HP but it loses
it's Flying type until the end of the turn. Also it's nickname, Acrobat,
A-Crobat. LOLOLOLOL._

![](What%20is%20a%20good%20in-
game%20team%20for%20Omega%20Ruby%20and%20Alpha%20Sapphire%3F%20\(page%203\)%20-%20Poke%CC%81Base%20Poke%CC%81mon%20Answers_files/image_002.png)  
**Manectric (Raiju)** @ Manecricite/Metronome  
Ability: Lightning Rod  > Intimidate

  * Volt Switch 
  * Thunderbolt 
  * Flamethrower 
  * Double Team 

_Manectric is a very fast and very strong but unfortunately lacks bulk however
getting Intimidate as he Mega Evolves does make up for this and he is usefull
for a few battles, mainly Winona and Wallace. Volt Switch allows a free hit
before you swap instead of just swapping out and Thunderbolt will be your main
STAB with a paralyse chance. Flamethrower is for coverage and is a good move
and Double Team will increase evasiveness which can allow free turns and with
Manectric's high speed it'll likely be able to get at least one off._

![](What%20is%20a%20good%20in-
game%20team%20for%20Omega%20Ruby%20and%20Alpha%20Sapphire%3F%20\(page%203\)%20-%20Poke%CC%81Base%20Poke%CC%81mon%20Answers_files/image_008.png)  
**Absol (Eclipse)** @ Absolite/Muscle Band  
Ability: Super Luck  > Magic Bounce

  * Swords Dance 
  * Night Slash 
  * Psycho Cut 
  * Rock Slide/Aerial Ace/X-Scissor/Shadow Claw 

_Absol is definitely a glass cannon having very small bulk but very high
attack but if used in the right circumstances and it will be a force to be
reckoned with. Swords Dance pretty much means you are ready to sweep but
having low defences makes this a risky but satisfying play. Night Slash is
main STAB and has a high Critical Hit ratio combined with Super luck this move
will be a critical almost all the time, same goes for Psycho Cut which is for
coverage. All the other moves are for coverage._

comments.content_original_markup:
This is the team I used in Omega Ruby.
I have listed HMs on all the Pokemon along with another move because I don't like using HM slaves. once I beat the main game I replace the HMs
BLAZIKEN

Ability: Blaze (Speed boost is better but it is difficult to obtain)
Item: Blazikenite or life orb
Moves:
- flare blitz
- rock smash (HM)/high jump kick
- stone edge/hidden power grass
- swords dance/protect (for speed boost)
Obviously you will want speed boost but it doesn't really matter if you intend to mega evolve it because it gets it then anyway. Flare blitz is the reliable STAB move and high jump kick is just another good stab option, but slightly risky, especially with the life orb. stone edge is good for dealing with flying types and some all round reliable coverage. hidden power grass is weaker than stone edge, but it covers two of blaziken's weakness. swords dance is a good setup move, but protect can help you raise your speed much easier.
BRELOOM

Ability: Effect spore (Again, Technician is better but more difficult to get)
Item: Life orb
Moves:
- seed bomb
- drain punch
- strenght (HM)/ mach punch
- swords dance/spore/toxic
Seed bomb is the reliable STAB damage, mach punch can deal with fast attackers with a lower defense very easily and drain punch recovers health. Swords dance is good for setting up breloom but in the long term spore or toxic may be more useful. Keep this thing away from flying types as it cant hit them or take hits from them.
SKARMORY

Ability: Sturdy
Item: Leftovers
Moves:
- fly (HM)/iron head
- roost
- whirlwind
- spikes
Skarmory has everything. Great defense, capable of doing damage, recovery and entry hazards. Fly is good enough as an attack but iron head can do better. Roost, leftovers and sturdy are great for stalling. whirlwind allows Skarmory to switch out anything resisting it and spikes is self explanatory.
ABSOL

Ability: Justified
Item: Absolite or life orb
Moves:
- cut (HM)/knock off
- sucker punch
- swords dance
- superpower
Once you get a swords dance off that sucker is deadly. In the main game knock off is useless, but if you want to play competitively, this can be useful. Superpower is for coverage.
FROSLASS

Ability: Snow cloak
Item: wise glasses
Moves:
- shadow ball
- ice beam
- destiny bond
- pain split
Froslass is a strong Pokemon, but is mainly here to cover the flying type weaknesses this team has and beat Drake. Ice beam and shadow ball are good STAB moves, while destiny bond and pain split can both be incredible options to have.
MILOTIC

Ability: competitive
Item: Leftovers
Moves:
- surf (HM)/Hydro pump
- dive (HM)/scald
- ice beam
- waterfall (HM)/recover
hydro pump does good damage and scald has the chance to burn. ice beam can kill grass types. it might look a bit like a HM slave, but dive and waterfall are both obtained very late in the game and surf can still do good damage.

OTHER OPTIONS
Milotic: Swampert/Sharpedo/Starmie
Froslass: Magnezone/Manectric
Absol: Dusknoir
Skarmory: Crobat/Swellow/Salamance/Altaria
Breloom: Roserade/Sceptile
Blaziken: Camerupt/Magcargo

If you would like to see my team for Alpha Sapphire, ask in the comments.

comments.content_original_markup:
This is my team for Omega Ruby. I hope it works well for you
(This is a mid-game team. Ex: nothing from Delta Episode, after becoming champion etc.)

#1 Sceptile -> Mega Sceptile
Ability: Overgrow -> Lightning Rod
Recommended Nature: Mild
Item: Sceptilite

Leaf Blade: Learnt at Level 23, STAB with high power
Dragon Claw: TM 01, another STAB move
Swords Dance: TM 75, boosts attack by 2 stages
Rock Slide: TM 80, deals with flying, fire and ice

#2 Camerupt
Ability: Solid Rock, Magma Armor
Recommended Nature: Modest
Item: Charcoal

Lava Plume: Learnt at Level 22, Decent power, STAB
Earth Power: Learnt at Level 26, Better than earthquake, cause of crap attack
Flash Cannon: TM 90, Deals with Rock and Ice types
Hidden Power (Electric): Deals with major weakness to Water

#3 Sharpedo
Ability: Rough Skin
Recommended Nature: Jolly
Item: Black Glasses

Crunch: Learnt at Level 40, Boosted by Black Glasses
Aqua Jet: Learnt at Level 11, Killer priority move
Waterfall: HM 08, You need it to clear the game
Ice Fang: Learnt at Level 25, Counters Grass type and Flying

#4 Slaking
Ability: Truant
Recommended Nature: Adamant
Item: Leftovers/Expert Belt

Feint Attack: Decent power, deals with Psychic and Ghost
Earthquake: STAB Ground move
Brick Break: Deals with other Normal, Rock, Ground, Ice and Steel
Facade: Do NOT give him a status condition...

#5 Togekiss
(You get him from the old lady in Lavaridge Town)
Ability: Serene Grace
Recommended Nature: Modest
Item: Flying Gem

Thunder Wave: Makes them slower than Togekiss
Air Slash: The infamous Para-Flinch Lock
Aura Sphere: Deals with Steel type, STAB
Dazzling Gleam: Who doesn't have Dazzling Gleam?

#6 Magnezone
Ability: Sturdy
Recommended Nature: Modest
Item: Rocky Helmet

Tri Attack: Has a chance to burn, paralyze or freeze
Rain Dance: Set up for Thunder, Really good STAB
Thunder: Never misses in the rain (Lol)
Flash Cannon: Good coverage for typing

I hope that this guide was useful to you!!

comments.content_original_markup:
Team Preview: Blaziken, Gardevoir, Swellow, Roserade, Flygon, Sharpedo/Milotic


Blaziken @ Blazikenite
Trait: Blaze > Speed Boost

  • Flare Blitz
  • High Jump Kick
  • Brave Bird
  • Earthquake/Stone Edge

Flare Blitz deals massive damage but it will do quite a lot of recoil damage, High Jump Kick is very risky but when it hits it does a lot of damage. Brave Bird also does a lot of recoil damage but it is very good for coverage and finally Earthquake and Stone Edge are excellent for coverage.

You can get the TM for Earthquake at the Seafloor Cavern and the TM for Stone Edge at the Lilycove department store.


Gardevoir @ Gardevoirite
Trait: Synchronize > Pixialte

  • Psychic
  • Moonblast
  • Shadow Ball
  • Calm Mind/Focus Blast

Psychic is a very reliable move with a lot of damage output as is Moonblast. Shadow ball is excellent for coverage, Calm Mind makes Gardevoir's moves even stronger and Focus Blast is good coverage.

You can get the TM for Shadow Ball in Mt. Pyre and you can get the TM for Focus Blast in the Lilycove Department Store.


Swellow @ Sharp Beak
Trait: Guts

  • Fly
  • Return
  • Steel Wing
  • U-Turn

Fly is powerful and handy for getting around the region and Return has a lot of power at max happiness. Steel Wing is good for coverage and U-Turn is good for chip damage and then a free swap.

Get HM Fly on Route 119 after beating May/Brendan in battle, get the TM for Return in Pacifidlog Town, get the TM for Steel Wing from Steven in Granite Cave and get the TM for U-Turn in Mauville City.


Roserade @ Big Root
Trait: Natural Cure

  • Giga Drain
  • Sludge Bomb
  • Sleep Powder
  • Dazzling Gleam/Shadow Ball

Giga Drain is very good for recovering HP and is pretty strong, Sludge Bomb is also very strong with a poison chance, Sleep Powder is surprisingly useful even if it misses sometimes and then Dazzling Gleam and Shadow Ball are good coverage.

Get the TM for Sludge Bomb from a collector in Dewford Hall, get the TM for Dazzling Gleam on Route 123 and TM for Shadow ball in Mt. Pyre.


Flygon @ Dragon Fang
Trait: Levitate

  • Dragon Claw
  • Earthquake
  • Rock Slide
  • Steel Wing/U-Turn

Despite Flygon being somewhat under powered, I had to put him in it. Dragon Claw is pretty poweful and reliable, Earthquake does huge damage, Rock Slide is great for coverage and the last moves are all for coverage.


Sharpedo @ Sharpedonite
Trait: Rough Skin > Tough Jaw

  • Surf/Waterfall
  • Ice Fang
  • Earthquake
  • Crunch

Surf and Waterfall are both required for progression so it's up to you which one you want to use, but they are both very strong. Ice Fang and Earthquake are excellent coverage and Crunch is a great STAB move.

Get the HM for Surf from Petalburg City after beating Norman and get the HM for Waterfall as a reward for beating Wallace.
Milotic @ Mystic Water
Trait: Marvel Scale

  • Surf
  • Ice Beam
  • Recover
  • Waterfall/Dive

Feebas is a pain in the ass to catch and evolve, but the annoyance is well worth it. Surf is necessary for progression and does a lot of damage, Ice Beam is great coverage, Recover helps Milotic stay alive and with its bulk, it stay up for a long lime and waterfall and Dive are needed for progression, so which one you use is up to you.

Get HM Dive from Steven after beating Tate and Lisa.
